subject: Re: [junit] Wha other alternatives to JUnit
msgSnippet: ... I don t have any specific references; however, I ll argue that JUnit is the representative implementation of unit testing with these requirements. 1. Tests
messageBody:
>So said Nikunj Manocha on 2003-07-08 --------------------
>Hi All,
>
> I am only doing a comparison study to why our project development
>team should use JUnit. JUnit testing is ingrained deeply into our
>development environment.
> I was wondering whether there is any other testing tool available
>which follows the concept of writing test code first? What features
>does JUnit offer over those test tools?
> Any information regarding these shall be very helpfull.

I don't have any specific references; however, I'll argue that JUnit is the representative implementation of unit testing with these requirements.

1. Tests must be automatic -- I push one button and they run.
2. Tests must verify themselves -- the test decides for itself whether it passes.
3. It must be possible to collect any group of tests into a suite.

If you start with these requirements, start writing tests, then factor out the repetitive parts, you'll get something very close to JUnit.

I would like to carry out this experiment sometime, but only as a Pair, because if I do it myself, my bias will lead to JUnit.

Take care.
